title: Tuesday, 13th November 2018

We can loop back to the bigger movers, the oil theme, the iPhone stuff and etc. But let's start with noodles.

Imperial Goldsmith Telecom Italia, any grey?

Gavin Darby’s off, finally.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Having been shouted at a lot at the AGM in July, he's decided there are easier ways to spend his time than fending off takeover interest and destroying shareholder value.

Dec69 - Skeptic Odds on for break up of Premier Foods now.
N5 Surely Vodafone, possibly Landsec?
BE11:24am

His departure and start of a piecemeal asset sale process looks like a victory for Oasis Management.

cloudy re P Foods - there's a rumour going around about a particular brand of butter. I'm not going to tell you what it is because you'll spread it.
Lemmy Dec69: not easy with the Nissin stake
BE11:25am

Though you'd have to expect they want more than the Ambrosia sale.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Here's Martin Deboo at Jefferies.

Excel Developer Question: Has the rolling bear market (re Morgan Stanley) finally reached the Tech stocks?
BE11:26am

Strong H1/Q2, well ahead of JEFe on both top and bottom line. Q2 sales were ahead 1.0%, well ahead of JEFe negative 3.7%. The core branded grocery business (60% of sales) was down only 2.7% against an exceptionally tough comp (JEFe down 11%). H1 trading profit of £51m was also well ahead of JEFe £48m and up 6% on the prior year.

Growth becoming a habit, against tough comps. PFD have now posted five consecutive quarters of growth. What sets Q2 apart is that it has been achieved against an exceptionally tough comp (+6.2% in the prior Q2 relative to negative 2.6% over the prior four), in the face of hot weather (a 110bps headwind in Q2) and a slowdown in International. Mr. Kipling, PFD's largest brand, grew double digit, with Batchelors, the fourth largest, growing 7%. But the inference is that sales growth was broadly based.

International slowing, but demand fundamentals continue to look positive. International sales (7-8% of the Group) fell by 9% in H1 (implying a c.20% decline in Q2) reflecting phasing of Cadbury Cake shipments to Australia and wholesaler price increases. Sales would have been 9% in H1 ex these effects, according to PFD.

BE11:26am

H1 profit and margins ahead. H1 trading profit of £51m & margins of 14.2% were ahead of JEFe £48m & 13.7% and prior year £48m & 13.6%. This despite a £2.4m. increase in central cost, on higher incentive payments, as guided. H1 profits look to have been supported by successful pricing and cost savings. While the prior H1 was impacted by cost recovery lags, we view the year-on-year progress, in tough markets, as encouraging.

Normal H1 cash generation. Continuing IAS19 surplus. H1 free cash outflow was similar to last year, reflecting normal seasonal NWC investment. Beyond that, higher EBITDA and lower capex was offset by higher NWC and higher financing fees consequent on the recent bond issue. Cash interest was materially lower, due to bond issue phasing. The IAS19 pension surplus, of £283m, was marginally below the £317m at year end.

FY outlook re-affirmed. Firmly on track to consensus. Profit and debt expectations are unchanged. Q3 in Sweet Treats is likely to be impacted by supply chain transition, but we judge this recoverable. The commitment to de-leverage to below 3.0x EBITDA by 2020 is reaffirmed. This will be impacted in FY19 by a c.£10m pre-Brexit stockbuild in H2. We view this as prudent. The FY19 consensus is looking for +2% sales growth and £126m trading profit (JEFe +0.5% & £127m). This looks eminently achievable, based on H1 momentum.

Exploring sale of Ambrosia. PFD reported that they are in discussions to dispose of Ambrosia, we think their third largest brand with sales of c. £90m. We get the logic, as Ambrosia is highly separable (a single factory in Devon) with associated minimal stranded cost (our central challenge to Oasis's Batchelors disposal thesis). However the exit multiple will need to be high single digit EBITDA to drive meaningful de-leverage. One to watch.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

CEO Gavin Darby to step down. CEO Gavin Darby is to step down at the end of January, after six years. We expect this to be taken positively by the shareholder base, given the strong negative vote against his re-election at the AGM in July. But we think his contribution has been under-estimated: he leaves behind in our view a more sustainably-growing, less leveraged and more harmonious PFD

BE11:27am

And Shore.

BE11:28am

Premier Foods has been a tumultuous story from the crazy days of foolhardy M&A to its position as a somewhat zombie investment in recent times. Its FY2019 interim results represent solid progress in far from ideal market conditions for its portfolio, leading to unchanged full-year guidance. However, Premier still carries a heavy legacy of past decision-making not least over half a billion pounds of debt that the banks have been happy to live off. Gavin Darby faced into the debt mountain and has materially improved Premier as a business. The debt has also come down but organic reduction is not a sustainable option. Hence, the Group is putting Ambrosia up for sale, let's see what emerges. The bid/no-bid hiatus clearly took its toll on Mr Darby and so it is understandable that he steps down in the New Year, we wish him well. Will a fresh pair of eyes and some Devon proceeds be enough to kill the Group's zombie status? Time will tell, HOLD for now.

shortfuse Late to the party....anything on IQE yet?
hornblower talking burgers, can anyone beat Meat Liqour
11:28 am
BE11:29am

Zombie because of the Nissin poison pill -- thanks Mr Darby! -- and the debt, of course.

BE11:29am

And given that, it's difficult to get overly excited either way.

...... leading to IQE sticking out a profit warning in the last moments of yesterday afternoon.

IQE PLC (IQE:LSE): Last: 70.40, up 3.4 (+5.07%), High: 75.65, Low: 67.55, Volume: 7.00m
Excel Developer Flattening yield curve can lead to higher volatility, https://twitter.com/excel_developer/status/1062306872135434240

(I note, incidentally, that we made the connection between Lumentum and IQE at 2pm yesterday: https://www.ft.com...-8a85-04b8afea6ea3 )

Tsetse Makes you wonder whether IIVI will continue down the road with Finisar. Talk about timing..
11:33 am
BE11:34am

(While the folks on the bulletin boards waffled on about tree shakes and shorters wanting their stock. I note this because, whenever we write anything even vaguely negative on IQE they write in in droves telling us we don't understand.)

cheeckychappy Bleecker does a great cheap burger but the fries aren't all that.
BE11:34am

So anyway, here's Peel's new numbers post warning.

Grouchmonkey Didn't IQE themselves warn on volumes earlier in the year?
BE11:36am

Yesterday, Lumentum, a manufacturer of laser light sources for 3D sensing [VCSELs], cut its 2FQ19 guidance by c7% [$70-75m estimated to be c.20m units]. This followed “a request from one of [its] largest customers … to materially reduce shipments to them during the quarter for previously placed orders”. On the back of this Lumentum announcement IQE now expects FY18E revenue to be c£160m [PHe £177m] and Adj EBITDA to be c£31m [PHe £44m].

11:35 am
BE11:36am

The deeper cut is a reflection of a very steep y/e ramp expected in the prior guidance given the use of inventory overbuild last year even into Oct. Photonics growth guidance for FY19E is unchanged at 40-60%, albeit starting from a lower-base. One thing Lumentum was keen to reiterate was the absence of market-share shifts. This is comforting.

BE11:36am

To us, as we noted in our initiation, these inventory dislocations are typical at this juncture of the market evolution. We remain convinced we are still at the foothills of the opportunity, and given the share price reaction yesterday, remains positive on IQE’s medium to longer-term value upside. What we found unsettling is the limits of visibility in this supply chain, which we assumed be at least three months

BE11:37am

And Stifel.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Our new estimates assume Apple related Photonics sales are down yy. IQE's Apple related sales in Photonics rose from £2m in 2016, £21m in 2017, and we assume this to be c.£18-19m for 2018e (was £33m before). IQE also has some additional Wireless $ content into Apple (via Skyworks for power amps) but we do not see this business as significantly impacted (IQE guided Wireless up 8% yy f/x adj., above the 0-5% original guide). We revise down our margins given less sales from the high margin Photonics (less leverage), resulting in our EPS estimates down 22%/25% for 2018e/19e

BE11:38am

The trading update could imply:
(i) Demand for the new iPhones could be softer than initially anticipated. The cheaper iPhone XR ($750) was only released three weeks ago (October 26) and so we suspect demand since release has been low. Evidence of more muted iPhone demand was already seen in the SepQ with the number of iPhones sold flat year on year and Apple's revenue guidance for the DecQ is up just 2% yy, despite the higher priced XS/XS Max released at the end of September. Lumentum/IQE's trading updates suggests unit demand for the iPhones is weaker than already lowered expectations (smartphone upgrade cycles lengthening).
(ii) Yields could be improving fast across the 3D sensing supply chain. If, for example, each 3D sensing supply chain partner sees yields improving from a c. 70% to 80% yield, then this could result in 2x the VCSEL chips produced than before. IQE is impacted by these yield improvements (lower volumes) albeit partially insulated with its direct chip customer as it prices its wafers based on a chips yielded basis.

cheeckychappy Dirty Burger best value...
BE11:38am

Which loops us back to Apple, the world's first trillion-dollar single product toy company.

cheeckychappy Along with Bleecker
Maverick Bleecker all the way!!!

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Goldman:

Gary Geezer Just here to support Bleecker, great burger
BE11:40am

We are reducing our FQ1’19 iPhone units estimate by 5% and FQ1 total revenue by 3% to $89bn. We also introduce our FY21 estimates. Our FQ1 revenue estimate is now at the low end of Apple’s guidance given on Nov 1 ($89bn-$93bn). While Apple may have already contemplated some weakness in its guidance, we feel the timing and magnitude of the LITE reduction suggests Apple is seeing incrementally worse demand data. We are reducing our 12-month PT to $209 based on ~16x P/E.

Excel Developer @Ethelred: It's Iran sanctions not being tight enough, I think. Waivers in place when not expected.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Oil? Okay. Still down. Oversupply fears.

Imperial Goldsmith Gotta be shake shack
BE11:44am

In the background the key fundamental change to the global oil S/D outlook over the last two weeks has been the US’s capitulation in enforcing Iran oil export sanctions – with Iran’s eight core customers (including maojr importers China and India) having been granted ‘temporary’ waivers for up to 180 days.
In response to the implied higher-for-longer-than-expected Iran exports, Saudi Arabia has stated it needs to cut production by 0.5mmb/d in December, and that OPEC/FSU combined needs to cut production by ~1.0mmb/d to prevent winter stock builds. The next OPEC meeting is planned for Dec 3rd.

MonkeyTrader @kiwi - not seen them myself yet....being told though it has big headline numbers again....Bryce got any colour?
BE11:45am

That's Numis.

GGekko @DJ - the black pudding middle i think didn't comply with USDA regs, but nothing ever confirmed by Bleecker. sad times
Excel Developer sanction waivers, told you.
11:45 am
BE11:45am

Despite rising early following indications from OPEC+ that production cuts are being considered for 2019 (and that Saudi Arabia is considering a 500kb/d cut in December), oil prices fell sharply later in the day immediately following a tweet from US President Donald Trump saying that oil prices should be "much lower" and expressing his hope that OPEC would not be cutting oil production. This was the latest in a number of tweets from the US leader that have appear to have had a significant impact on oil markets. A number of macro datapoints are coming today with the OPEC Monthly Oil Market Report and the EIA's Drilling Productivity Report, which will add some basinlevel detail on the recent increase to the EIA's US production forecasts.

BE11:46am

That's UBS.

Excel Developer was Trump's tweet about wanting lower oil before or after mid terms? this matters.
BE11:47am

And against that you have the strategy bumf.

nightingale20201 T's tweet was overnight
11:47 am
BE11:47am

Morgan Stanley saying take profit, for instance.

BE11:48am

Relative dividend yields have reverted to the historical mean,
providing less room for further yield compression. Also,
consensus FCF expectations are now demanding, following large upgrades in recent months. With the forward curve moving towards contango - a bearish sign - we cut to In-Line.

Excel Developer ta
BE11:48am

After outperforming in 2016 and 2017, Oil & Gas has been the best performing sector in Europe this year as well. Our 'Attractive' sector stance was based on the expectation that a combination of cost savings, capex cuts and oil price recovery would boost FCF. In turn, this would put the majors' dividends on a more secure footing, and drive elevated dividend yields down, back to their historical average vs the market. We think this process has largely run its course.

nightingale20201 saw some oil curve earlier...crude seems to be in backwardation
11:48 am
BE11:49am

Scope for dividend yield compression is much reduced and FCF estimates are now more demanding, they say.

Ethelred He also tweeted in July saying Saudis were likely to maintain production
BE11:49am

Plus "the forward curve is on the brink of contango - historically, a bearish indicator".

Excel Developer "Oil & Gas has been the best performing sector in Europe this year as well. " Other Europe stocks not much competition, though.
BE11:49am

Since 1999, there have been five periods during which the Brent curve was in contango, varying in length from just 2 months to ~3 years. During these five periods, the sector consistently underperformed the market, by (15)%, (3)%, (16)%, (15)% and (34)%. On the back of Sunday's OPEC announcement, Brent time spreads have recovered modestly but the tailwind from a backwardated curve appears to have gone.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

BP and Total still overweight on valuation.

Dec69 - Skeptic IQE hangs on by a thread, surely with launch demand would have been strong?
BE11:50am

Repsol overweight on downstream.

BE11:50am

"we believe the market is under-appreciating the tailwind from the coming IMO regulation"

Ethelred July Trumptweet: Just spoke to King Salman of Saudi Arabia and explained to him that, because of the turmoil & disfunction in Iran and Venezuela, I am asking that Saudi Arabia increase oil production, maybe up to 2,000,000 barrels, to make up the difference...Prices to [sic] high!
11:50 am
BE11:50am

But sell everything else. Says them.

undefined
Excel Developer So what? Do we wait for oil to bottom out before buying BP equity?
shortfuse Is IQE purely reliant on iPhone sales? I was led to believe that Samsung were making use of the 3D sensing tech?
BE11:51am

Since we're in big strat -- and you know how much I enjoy big strat -- want UBS's 2019 preview?

11:51 am
BE11:51am

The equity market is starting to behave as if we are moving into the end of the cycle: P/E multiples are de-rating ahead of any major fall in earnings estimates (Figure 1). The 2018 de-rating has been the largest in 7 years. But we only see a small moderation in growth: our top-down earnings model points to 7% EPS growth in 2019 and 3% in 2020. We target 420 Stoxx 600 end-2019 and 7,600 FTSE 100.

Excel Developer yes please Bryce!
BE11:52am

It's November 13. It's no time to be releasing 2019 previews.

nightingale20201 fyi, there has been a disconnect, in terms of price performance, between the oil majors and the underlying oil prices
Dec69 - Skeptic Did someone knife catch the end of cycle?
BE11:52am

Anyway, their six themes are:

11:52 am
BE11:52am

1) the Italian budget – Eurozone banks' correlation to Italian bonds are at a 6 year high, 2) need for clarity on Brexit, 3) potential for a turn in the China data, 4) the outlook for US rates, 5) the self-balancing move in US bond yields, 6) can the rest of the world catch up with the US? and, 7) de-escalation of trade wars?

shortfuse @dec69 Not yet but it's one I follow.
Fox Hello? Vodafone?
BE11:53am

Upshot here is that European stocks are at a 20 per cent discount to the long-term average so has priced in double-digit EPS downgrades.

Dec69 - Skeptic The bond market has to go tits up soon. How the hell people buy debt in crappy company's is beyond me. the end of cheap money is soon!
BE11:54am

Yet "UBS bottom-up analysts expect EBIT margins to rise 80bps in 2019, and even then we would be 80bps below the previous peak. The latest UBS Evidence Lab survey showed that companies see pricing power improving, suggesting they can pass on costs."

Excel Developer @BE: will that make its way into the usual place?
11:54 am
BE11:54am

So buy miners.

BE11:54am

With the market partially pricing an end of cycle event but, in our view, the economic cycle having further to go, late cycle plays such as Mining are in a particularly strong position. We upgrade Mining to Overweight on strong cashflow and dividend yields, positive commodity price outlook, attractive valuations and potential upside from Chinese stimulus. We also downgrade Real Estate to Underweight as it outperformed YTD despite the rise in yields. But EPS momentum now appears to be fading and European spreads between corporate bond yields and residential yields have shrunk to the lowest levels since 2013.

undefined
Excel Developer Breaking: Trump trolling Macron
11:54 am
BE11:54am

(@Excel: I don't know, I don't go there.)

BE11:55am

Sometimes, ROTR, it's like trying to mind a nursery class. Yes, okay, Vodafone.

Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 156.22, up 11.86 (+8.22%), High: 158.80, Low: 152.04, Volume: 87.66m
11:55 am
BE11:55am

It's all about the divi.

BE11:56am

You're still getting one. It won't go up, but it won't go down either.

Gary Geezer Any grey on Melrose pls Bryce?
Excel Developer I've just trolled Trump on behalf of Macron, https://twitter.com/excel_developer/status/1062313084876922880
madrugada Could today's results from VOD and FGP see a positive upside being maintained over the coming months?
BE11:59am

Nick Read talks about cost savings and top-line growth, edges up the FCF targets, that kind of thing. Which post the stuff about Vodafone's divi being impossible against the Liberty debt and price wars in .... everywhere ........ is being seen as broadly reassuring.

Dec69 - Skeptic How's Reliance Jio coping now onboarding costs near 10fold more?
11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Who can I quote here? Vodafone analysis is always a struggle to read.

BE12:00pm

Citi will do.

BE12:01pm

VOD reported decent 1H19 numbers, which confirmed a slowdown but a much milder one than expected. Service revenues slowdown from 0.3% to - 0.5% [+0.5% excluding handset financing in the UK], vs -0.7% for Citi [-0.6% for Cons]; though that was driven by a positive one-off in South Africa. EBITDA grew by 2.9% and VOD expects organic EBITDA growth of 3% for the full year [vs range of 1-5% before]. VOD has also raised its guidance for organic FCF generation to €5.4bn vs €5.2bn before. Finally, it expects the FY19 dividend to be in line with 2018 [growth before]. The company will consider paying a growing dividend in the long term once leverage moves to the lower end of the 2.5-3.0x net debt/EBITDA range [which was revised for the acquisition of LBTY assets].

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

German comps were tough and loss of wholesale share (from 1&1 migration to TEF De) is impacting numbers, but commercial momentum is strong in both broadband and mobile and so is EBITDA momentum at 7%. Spain is clearly the weak point after a dramatic deterioration to - 7.2%. We believe the worst should be over in terms of both churn and revenue weakness of football related churn should normalize in the coming quarters and comps get easier on top line. Italy was mixed with high prepaid churn but stable financials (due to phasing of tariff adjustments). The outlook for 2H should be more stable as competition has been easing steadily since Iliad’s lunch in June. Rest of Europe was solid, UK showing further improvement as the market is on the mend.

BE12:01pm

We believe that given the negative sentiment and concerns going into the results, both the numbers and the key messages should reassure. The FCF uptick due to confidence on the mid-point of EBITDA and higher contribution from Ziggo should give more confidence on cover. Given positive FX since the summer, there is another tailwind for consensus estimates, currently at €5.1bn. The stable dividend provides support but also shows an acknowledgement that growth is credible only if EBITDA/FCF growth can keep leverage in check, especially in light of the Italian spectrum outlay.

Dec69 - Skeptic @madrugada I can't find any reason to own public transport providers. You've seen the stats for Greyhound in the US?
BE12:03pm

Dec69 mentions Reliance Jio .... And it's worth picking out the India figures here, even though they're irrelevant in a group context.

Dec69 - Skeptic @BE, why does analysis never cover the deflationary elements of competition, its savage out there, reflected in the writedowns, even in their 'new venture' type JV's.
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Vod through another €1.3bn into the Idea subsidiary in H1 to avoid a default.

Excel Developer Bloomberg's Gina Martin Adams says Tech trade capitulating.
BE12:04pm

Net debt/ebitda's at a hilarious 9.7x.

Cash man @BE "threw"?
BE12:05pm

I mention that in the context of a group balance sheet that still doesn't look great.

Dec69 - Skeptic What could go wrong... lets have a "Cellular Idea", (See what I did there). I'm curious how Jio gets users to pay going forward. Ah what the heck, who cares.
12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

(@Cash man: gold star. Thanks.)

BE12:05pm

Here's SocGen.

BE12:05pm

We note that in 1H18/19 net debt increased by €2.5bn (representing an 8.4% increase from the level six months earlier) with only €808m spectrum auction fees booked over the period. With the balance still to be booked in 2H (the Italian spectrum auction alone cost an overall €2.4bn), and more spectrum auctions projected in Germany and South-Africa, we expect debt to increase further. Furthermore, with EBITDA down 4.2% yoy (a growth rate likely to be mirrored in 2H), we project a tangible rise in gearing compared with the levels projected by credit agencies only six months ago. Importantly, what drives balance sheet gearing is “headline” not “organic” growth.

madrugada Dec69: yes. Is it a recovery play?
Dec69 - Skeptic When you have to 'hold' firm on promises to pay a dividend, rather than operate with financial prudence, the outlook may be distorted by divi chasers, the reality, another thing. Who cares about organic revenue deflation.
12:07 pm
undefined
Dec69 - Skeptic madrugada, I'd rather see a recovery or even a glimmer of it on a sustained basis. @BE Anything on Interserve's death spiral, have the bulls capitulated yet?
Excel Developer Oil off 20% now, bear market. official.
BE12:08pm

Let me knock a few requests out and then we can all get on with our lives.

photon silence therapeutics went over a cliff just after alphas mention that the yanks were possibly interested the other day at 120 ..now its recovered a bit and hanging on at 92..seems there is a court case in December.
BE12:08pm

Melrose statement's okay against what was expected, given a fair percentage of Melrose is now an auto parts maker.

12:09 pm
BE12:10pm

With a lot of debt. Here's Barclays.

BE12:10pm

Melrose has de-rated 26% since the H1 update on 6 September in spite of upgrades to TR consensus EPS of 8% and the FTSE 100 only down 4%. We put this down to growing concern over leverage (2.5x Net Debt to EBITDA at FY18E vs. a 3.5x covenant) due to the company’s exposure to what has been viewed as a deteriorating autos market. The bear thesis was that: a roll-over of the autos cycle would severely impact the EBIT of the Automotive and Powder Met divisions (Powder Met has ~75% exposure to the autos industry) which represent 49% of our group EBIT in FY19E; and that the company would not be able to de-lever by disposals at attractive multiples as Powder Met would be weighed down by the autos market and Nortek would be weighed down by tariff uncertainty.

Dec69 - Skeptic @Excel, the hedging activity suggested a peek (scuse the pun) in Brent/WTI, without a requirement for hindsight.
BE12:10pm

They're still buyers.

Soundbuy Pics of Lonsdale gear being stocked in House of Fraser this am..........this heralds the apocalypse I believe........
12:10 pm
BE12:11pm

The shares trade on ~11x FY19E PER and EV/EBIT. We continue to find it an interesting reference point that:

· The shares need to rise by ~45% before management begin to accrue an LTIP (the LTIP represented 90% of 2013-17 comp); and

· Management's target of doubling of GKN equity in five years implies ~100% upside potential from current levels.

Dec69 - Skeptic @Soundbuy, we look forward to a selfie!
BE12:11pm

As are Stifel.

BE12:12pm

Melrose has issued a brief but reassuring Q3 trading update. Few numbers are provided in the release but the message is clear: a strong performance at Aerospace (and, to a lesser extent Powder Met) has offset a softer period at Auto, as the group navigates turbulence in that market - although even Auto is not as bad as some may have feared. Auto revenues are flat YoY in Q3, through the major WLTP disruption to the EU end market, and a soft period in China. Overall group full year expectations appear unchanged, and we believe that 2019 numbers also still look realistic, albeit with the mix of earnings again shifted (higher aero offsetting lower auto). Finally, we are encouraged by the robust performance at Powder Met (9% growth and increased margins): this not only helps the bottom line, but also supports potential disposal values. So while Auto is undoubtedly (if unsurprisingly) weak and Norkek looks mixed, the group has managed to make better than expected progress elsewhere, and looks set to meet FY consensus expectations as a result. That should provide some relief, in our view. Retain Buy.

BE12:16pm

Firstgroup’s H1 results indicate several encouraging trends in the Road division, albeit in the less material first half. Total Road CC revenue grew 2.0% and operating profit grew of 17.9% y/y. Rail earnings are a minor offset, falling 5.8% y/y. The group is executing a recovery plan in Greyhound, with at least mid-single digit margins expected in the medium term. The group has not declared an interim dividend.

BE12:16pm

Our group P&L forecasts are largely unchanged for FY19e, with some moderate upgrades to future years. Divisionally, Road earnings are increased, with Rail forecasts being reduced primarily due to South West. We remain Overweight Firstgroup given the material self-help story and medium term refinancing potential. Our PT is unchanged at 133p.
